message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute appendicitis, which is confirmed by the ultrasonography. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a laparoscopic appendectomy, which is the standard treatment for acute appendicitis. Beginning bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration or prescribing oral antibiotics would not be effective in treating the condition, and percutaneous drainage is not typically used in the management of appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings strongly suggest acute appendicitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a laparoscopic appendectomy. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration are not indicated for acute appendicitis. Percutaneous drainage is not appropriate for uncomplicated acute appendicitis. Prescribing oral antibiotics alone is not an appropriate treatment for acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical exam findings, and ultrasonography all suggest acute appendicitis. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a laparoscopic appendectomy. Options A and C are not appropriate as the patient requires surgical management. Option B may be considered in selected cases but is not the first-line option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and imaging all strongly suggest acute appendicitis. The appropriate next step would be to perform a laparoscopic appendectomy, as this is the standard treatment for acute appendicitis. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate management for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows signs of acute appendicitis, with severe right lower quadrant tenderness and elevated leukocyte count. The dilation and echogenic periappendiceal fat seen on ultrasonography confirm the diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a laparoscopic appendectomy to remove the inflamed appendix. Options A, B, and C are not appropriate in the management of acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute appendicitis. The ultrasonography also supports this diagnosis. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration are not necessary in the initial management of appendicitis. Percutaneous drainage is not recommended for non-complicated appendicitis. Oral antibiotics are not typically used as the sole treatment for acute appendicitis. Laparoscopic appendectomy is the appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination, and imaging results are consistent with acute appendicitis. The most appropriate next step in management is performing a laparoscopic appendectomy. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration are not indicated in the treatment of acute appendicitis. Percutaneous drainage is not appropriate for a non-perforated appendix, and oral antibiotics alone are not sufficient treatment for acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings strongly suggest acute appendicitis. Abdominal ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is started to prepare for surgery. Laparoscopic appendectomy is the most appropriate next step in management as it is the preferred method for surgical intervention in uncomplicated acute appendicitis. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration, percutaneous drainage, and oral antibiotics are not the first-line interventions for uncomplicated acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests acute appendicitis, which requires surgical intervention. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration are non-operative interventions and not the first line of management. Percutaneous drainage has not been shown to be effective for appendicitis. Antibiotics may be used as an adjunct to surgery but are not the definitive treatment. Laparoscopic appendectomy is the most appropriate next step in management for acute appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute appendicitis. Abdominal ultrasonography also confirms a dilated, noncompressible appendix. The most appropriate next step is laparoscopic appendectomy, which is the standard treatment for acute appendicitis. Bowel rest and nasogastric aspiration, percutaneous drainage, and prescribing oral antibiotics would not be appropriate for this patient's presentation.
